text.p: Following are the main stories in Slovenia's Thursday morning newspapers.
- Prime Minister Janez Drnovsek said European statesmen claimed Slovenia was very likely to be invited to join NATO at the alliance's summit in 1999.
- About 12 Slovenian businessmen are attending a Central European economic summit in Salzburg this week.
- Employers rejected a demand of the trade union that basic salaries be increased by 3.7 percent from July in order to catch up with the inflation rate.
- Although Slovenia's GDP only rose 2.2 percent in the first quarter of 1997, the government Institute of Macroeconomic Analysis said the 1997 GDP growth goal of four percent would remain unchanged.
- About 44.7 percent of Slovenians believe the country should speed up its highway programme, while 45.1 percent said the current pace of highway construction was sufficient, an opinion poll showed.
- U.S. President Bill Clinton told Prime Minister Drnovsek during their meeting in Madrid that he was considering a visit to Slovenia.
